case_name: Appellant Company v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 830 of 1963 was filed by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 3, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 830 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 3, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

facts.text: The appellants are a public limited company having its registered office at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants public limited Company--having its registered office at Calcutta,

facts.text: The appellant company was appointed sole agent for sale of goods manufactured by the Swadeshi Cotton Mills Company Ltd. with effect from October 5, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: was, with effect from October 5, 1946, appointed sole agent for sale of goods manufactured by the Swadeshi Cotton Mills Company Ltd.

facts.text: On March 20, 1952, the Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur issued a notice under s. 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 calling upon the appellant Company to file a return for the assessment year 1948-49 as turnover had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1952, the Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur issued a numberice under s. 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 calling upon the appellant Company to file a return of its turnover for the assessment year 1948-49 on the ground that the turnover had escaped assessment.

facts.text: On March 31, 1952, the Sales Tax Officer made a best judgment assessment determining the taxable turnover of the appellant Company at Rs. 50 lakhs for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1952, the Sales Tax Office.- made a best judgment assessment and determined the taxable turnover of the appellant Company, at Rs. 50 lakhs for the year 1948-49 and determined the appropriate tax liability.

facts.text: In appeal to the Judge (Appeals) Sales Tax, the order of the Sales Tax Officer was set aside holding that the appellant Company was not a dealer within s. 2(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal to the Judge  Appeals  Sales Tax, the order passed by the Sales Tax Officer, was set aside, that authority holding that the appellant Company was number a dealer within the meaning of s. 2 c  of the Act.

facts.text: The order of the Judge (Appeals) Sales Tax was set aside by the Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax by order dated March 28, 1955 and the case was remanded to the Sales Tax Officer for fresh assessment.

anchor.surface_text: But the order of the appellate authority was set aside by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax, by order dated March 28, 1955 and the case was remanded to the Sales Tax Officer for fresh assessment.

facts.text: Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax held it necessary to determine the ownership of the goods at the time of their sale.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax, it was necessary to determine the ownership of the goods at the time of their sale.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer issued notice on July 23, 1955 calling upon the appellant Company to produce books of account for assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer then issued a numberice calling, upon the appellant Company to produce its books of account and other relevant documents on July 23, 1955 for the purpose of assessment for the year 1948-49.

facts.text: Appellant Company contended that no proceeding was pending after set aside by Judge (Revisions) and re-assessment barred as more than three years elapsed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company companytended that as the original assessment under s. 21 had been set aside by the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax, numberproceeding in companynection with that assessment was pending and re-assessment was barred because more than three year had elapsed since the end of the year of assessment.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected the contention of the appellant Company and insisted on production of books.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer rejected the companytention of the appellant Company and insisted that the books of account and other documents be produced as directed earlier.

facts.text: On September 2, 1955, appellant Company petitioned Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 for writ of prohibition and certiorari against Sales Tax Officer for 1948-49 assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company then petitioned on September 2, 1955 to the High Court of Allahabad under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of prohibition restraining the Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur, from proceeding with the assessment of the appellant Company for the assessment year 1948-49 and for a writ of certiorari quashing the order dated September 2, 1955 of the Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur and the proceeding taken for re-assess- ment in pursuance thereof.

facts.text: Chaturvedi J. held the assessment barred by limitation under s.21 U.P. Sales Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Chaturvedi J., held that assessment sought to be made by the Sales Tax Officer pursuant to the order of the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax was clearly barred by the law of limitation prescribed in that behalf by S. 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court reversed Chaturvedi J., holding Sales Tax Officer competent and s.21 limitation not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by Chaturvedi J., was reversed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court. The High Court held that the Sales Tax Officer was companypetent in view of the order of remand which directed fresh assessment to companymence fresh assessment proceedings against the appellant Company and in companymencing and companytinuing those proceedings he was acting in companypliance with the directions given under ss. 9 and 10 of the Act which he was bound to carry out and to such assessment proceedings the period of limitation prescribed by S. 21 of the Act did number apply.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 830 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 3, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

facts.text: S. 21 of U.P. Sales Tax Act originally provided for assessment of escaped turnover within three years from expiry of the year.

anchor.surface_text: Section 21 as it stood at the relevant time provided Where the whole or any part of the turnover of a dealer has, for any reason, escaped assessment to tax in any year, the Assessing Authority may, at any time within three years from the expiry of such years, and after issuing numberice to the dealer and making such enquiry as may be necessary, assess the tax payable on such turnover.

facts.text: S.21 amended by Act 19 of 1956 from May 28, 1956 with retrospective effect from enactment of principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: But the order of the High Court must still be companyfirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended. The section as amended by Act 19 of 1956 from May 28, 1956 reads as follows

facts.text: Amended s.21 provides no limitation for assessment in consequence of order under s.9,10,11.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that numberhing companytained in this section limiting the time within which any assessment or re-assessment may be made, shall apply to an assessment or re-assessment made in companysequence of, or to give effect to, any finding or direction companytained in an order under section 9, 10, or 11.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court erred in limiting s.21 only to suo motu actions.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was in error in so limiting the operation of s. 21. That section imposes a restriction upon the power of the Sales Tax Officer that officer is companypetent within three years next succeeding the date to which the tax relates to assess tax payable on the turnover which has escaped assessment.

facts.text: Appellant contended even amended s.21 applies only to pending proceedings, but no proceeding pending as original s.21 period expired.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak on behalf of the appellant Company pleaded that even if that be the true interpretation of s. 21 as amended, the section companyld only apply to proceedings which were pending at the date on which the Act was amended, but in law numberproceeding was pending because the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax had numberpower to direct after the expiry of the period prescribed under s. 21 as it originally stood to make a fresh assessment in respect of the year 1948-49.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellant's contention holding revisional order valid and proceeding pending.

anchor.surface_text: There are two clear answers to this plea, either of which is sufficient to reject it. The revisional authority had under s. 10 3  power to make such order as he thought fit after calling for and examining the record of any order made by an appellate or an assessing authority and after satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order.

facts.text: Amended s.21 deemed in operation from enactment of U.P. Sales Tax Act 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The amended section was therefore to be deemed to be in operation at all material times since the enactment of the P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948.

issues.text: Whether the period of limitation under section 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 (as originally enacted) applies to re-assessments directed by appellate or revisional authorities under sections 9 and 10

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the High Court s. 21 which imposed upon the Assessing Authority duty to exercise his power to assess turnover which escaped assessment within three years from the end of the year of assessment applied only to the order which the Assessing Authority made suo motu where, he was directed to,

issues.text: Whether the amendment to section 21 by U.P. Sales Tax (Amendment) Act 19 of 1956 applies retrospectively from the commencement of the principal Act

anchor.surface_text: The section as amended by Act 19 of 1956 from May 28, 1956 reads as follows If the assessing authority has reason to believe that the whole or any part of the turnover of a dealer has, for any reason, escaped assessment to tax for any year, the assessing authority may, after issuing notice to the dealer, and making such enquiry as may be necessary, assess or re-assess him to tax

issues.text: Whether the limitation period under sub-section (2) of amended section 21 applies to an assessment or re-assessment made in consequence of or to give effect to any finding or direction contained in an order under sections 9, 10 or 11

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that nothing contained in this section limiting the time within which any assessment or re-assessment may be made, shall apply to an assessment or re-assessment made in consequence of, or to give effect to, any finding or direction contained in an order under section 9, 10, or 11.

anchor.surface_text: There was, therefore, a proceeding pending before the Sales Tax Officer in pursuance of the direction given by the Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax who had directed the Sales Tax Officer to make a fresh assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional authority had under s. 10 (3) power to make such order as he thought fit after calling for and examining the record of any order made by an appellate or an assessing authority and after satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order.

arguments.claim: Assessment by Sales Tax Officer pursuant to order of Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax barred by limitation under s.21 regardless of whether suo motu or under direction of superior authority

anchor.surface_text: Chaturvedi J., held that assessment sought to be made by the Sales Tax Officer pursuant to the order of the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax was clearly barred by the law of limitation prescribed in that behalf by S. 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act. It was in the view of the learned Judge immaterial whether assessment was being made by the Sales Tax Officer suo motu or under the direction of a superior authority if at the time of making the re-assessment the period prescribed by S. 21 had expired.

arguments.qualifiers: in the view of the learned Judge

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed s.21 applies even to directed assessments but amendment overrides limitation

arguments.claim: Sales Tax Officer competent to proceed with fresh assessment per remand order under ss.9 and 10 and s.21 limitation does not apply to such proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by Chaturvedi J., was reversed in appeal by a Division Bench of the High Court. The High Court held that the Sales Tax Officer was companypetent in view of the order of remand which directed fresh assessment to companymence fresh assessment proceedings against the appellant Company and in companymencing and companytinuing those proceedings he was acting in companypliance with the directions given under ss. 9 and 10 of the Act which he was bound to carry out and to such assessment proceedings the period of limitation prescribed by S. 21 of the Act did number apply.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: held that assessment sought to be made by the Sales Tax Officer pursuant to the order of the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax was clearly barred by the la

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court erred in limiting s.21 only to suo motu actions; s.21 restriction applies to all including directed reassessments

arguments.claim: s.21 imposes restriction on power of Sales Tax Officer to assess escaped turnover within three years applicable even to reassessments pursuant to directions of appellate or revisional authority under ss.9 and 10

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was in error in so limiting the operation of s. 21. That section imposes a restriction upon the power of the Sales Tax Officer that officer is companypetent within three years next succeeding the date to which the tax relates to assess tax payable on the turnover which has escaped assessment. But the section does number provide expressly, number is there any implication, that the period within which re-assessment may be made applies only to those cases where the Sales Tax Officer acts on his own initiative and number pursuant to the directions of the appel- late or the revisional authority.

arguments.claim: Principle from Privy Council in Khemchand Ramdas applies: reassessment pursuant to revisional direction also subject to limitation period under s.21

anchor.surface_text: In our view the principle of the judgment of the Privy Council in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas  a firm   1  applies to this case. In Khemchands case 1  the tax-payer was assessed as a registered firm to income- tax by order dated January 17, 1927 for the year 1926-27 under s. 23 4  of the Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Amended s.21 by Act 19 of 1956 applies with no limitation for assessments in consequence of orders under ss.9,10,11 and has retrospective effect from enactment of principal Act

anchor.surface_text: But the order of the High Court must still be companyfirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended. The section as amended by Act 19 of 1956 from May 28, 1956 reads as follows... Provided further that numberhing companytained in this section limiting the time within which any assessment or re-assessment may be made, shall apply to an assessment or re-assessment made in companysequence of, or to give effect to, any finding or direction companytained in an order under section 9, 10, or 11.

arguments.claim: Even if true interpretation of amended s.21, it only applies to pending proceedings but no proceeding was pending as Judge (Revisions) had no power to direct fresh assessment after expiry under original s.21

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak on behalf of the appellant Company pleaded that even if that be the true interpretation of s. 21 as amended, the section companyld only apply to proceedings which were pending at the date on which the Act was amended, but in law numberproceeding was pending because the Judge  Revisions  Sales Tax had numberpower to direct after the expiry of the period prescribed under s. 21 as it originally stood to make a fresh assessment in respect of the year 1948-49.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d  ii  that, numberhing companytained in s 21 which limits the time within which any assessment or re- assessment is to be made applies to assessment

arguments.court_reasoning: Revisional authority had power under s.10(3) to make such order; proceeding pending; amended s.21 deemed in operation retrospectively

arguments.claim: Revisional authority under s.10(3) had jurisdiction to direct fresh assessment even after expiry of original s.21 limitation; order valid unless set aside; proceeding pending before STO

anchor.surface_text: There are two clear answers to this plea, either of which is sufficient to reject it. The revisional authority had under s. 10 3  power to make such order as he thought fit after calling for and examining the record of any order made by an appellate or an assessing authority and after satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order. Even assuming that the revisional authority came to a companyclusion which was erroneous in law, it was still an order which he had jurisdiction to make and that order unless set aside in a proper proceeding companyld number be ignored on the ground of lack of jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: By s.15 of Act 19/1956, amended s.21 deemed substituted from enactment of principal Act so no limitation bar for assessment pursuant to revisional order

anchor.surface_text: The amended section was therefore to be deemed to be in operation at all material times since the enactment of the P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948. The Legislature has given a clear retrospective operation to the amended section as from the date on which the principal Act came into operation, and companyrectness of the order of the Sales Tax Officer holding that there was numberbar of limitation to the making of a fresh assessment pursuant to the order of the appellate or revising authority had to be adjudged in the light of s. 21 as amended by Act 19 of 1956.

holdings.text: Section 21 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 (original) imposes a time restriction on the power of the Sales Tax Officer to assess escaped turnover that applies even to re-assessments made pursuant to directions of appellate or revisional authorities under sections 9 and 10.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was in error in so limiting the operation of s. 21. That section imposes a restriction upon the power of the Sales Tax Officer that officer is competent within three years next succeeding the date to which the tax relates to assess tax payable on the turnover which has escaped assessment. But the section does number provide expressly, number is there any implication, that the period within which re-assessment may be made applies only to those cases where the Sales Tax Officer acts on his own initiative and number pursuant to the directions of the appel- late or the revisional authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court wrongly limited s.21 to suo motu actions; textual reading shows general restriction on STO power with no express/implied exception for directed assessments; applies principle from Privy Council in Khemchand Ramdas by analogy.

holdings.text: The amendment to section 21 by U.P. Sales Tax (Amendment) Act 19 of 1956 is retrospective and deemed in operation from the enactment of the principal Act.

anchor.surface_text: The amended section was therefore to be deemed to be in operation at all material times since the enactment of the P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948. The Legislature has given a clear retrospective operation to the amended section as from the date on which the principal Act came into operation, and correctness of the order of the Sales Tax Officer holding that there was numberbar of limitation to the making of a fresh assessment pursuant to the order of the appellate or revising authority had to be adjudged in the light of s. 21 as amended by Act 19 of 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 15 of amending Act expressly provides for substitution 'as it shall always be deemed to have been'; clear legislative intent for retrospectivity from principal Act's commencement.

holdings.text: No period of limitation under sub-section (2) of amended section 21 applies to an assessment or re-assessment made in consequence of, or to give effect to, any finding or direction contained in an order under sections 9, 10 or 11.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that numberhing companytained in this section limiting the time within which any assessment or re-assessment may be made, shall apply to an assessment or re-assessment made in companysequence of, or to give effect to, any finding or direction companytained in an order under section 9, 10, or 11.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of second proviso to amended s.21; precise words admit only one interpretation exempting such assessments from time limits.

holdings.text: A proceeding was pending before the Sales Tax Officer pursuant to the direction of the Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax for fresh assessment.

anchor.surface_text: There was, therefore, a proceeding pending before the Sales Tax Officer in pursuance of the direction given by the Judge (Revisions) Sales Tax who had directed the Sales Tax Officer to make a fresh assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revisional order directing fresh assessment created pending proceeding before STO; order valid until set aside.

holdings.text: The revising authority under section 10(3) had jurisdiction to direct fresh assessment notwithstanding expiry of the limitation period under original section 21.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional authority had under s. 10 3  power to make such order as he thought fit after calling for and examining the record of any order made by an appellate or an assessing authority and after satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.10(3) confers plenary power to pass any order deemed fit after examining legality/propriety; even if erroneous, order has jurisdiction unless set aside; reinforced by retrospective amendment.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the High Court was in error in so limiting the operation of s. 21. That section imposes a restriction upon the power of the Sales Tax Officer that officer is competent within three years next succeeding the date to which the tax relates to assess tax payable on the turnover which has escaped assessment. But the section does number provide expressly, number is there any implication, that the period within which re-assessment may be made applies only to those cases where the Sales Tax Officer acts on his own initiative and number pursuant to the directions of the appel- late or the revisional authority.
But the order of the High Court must still be confirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended.
panysequence of, or to give effect to an order of the appellate or revising authority or an order passed by the High Court under s. 11 may be taken nu

edges.explanation: h2 holds amendment retrospective from principal Act, addressing i2

anchor.surface_text: The amended section was therefore to be deemed to be in operation at all material times since the enactment of the P. Sales Tax Act 15 of 1948. The Legislature has given a clear retrospective operation to the amended section as from the date on which the principal Act came into operation, and correctness of the order of the Sales Tax Officer holding that there was numberbar of limitation to the making of a fresh assessment pursuant to the order of the appellate or revising authority had to be adjudged in the light of s. 21 as amended by Act 19 of 1956.
But the order of the High Court must still be confirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended.

But the order of the High Court must still be confirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional authority had under s. 10 3  power to make such order as he thought fit after calling for and examining the record of any order made by an appellate or an assessing authority and after satisfying himself as to the legality or propriety of such order.
But the order of the High Court must still be confirmed, because during the pendency of the proceeding in the High Court s. 21 was extensively amended.
